answer:
**Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis:**

1. **Frame 1:** We see a multi‐lane downtown street with traffic moving in our direction (toward the camera). No explicit “One Way” sign is visible yet, but there is a large tanker truck in the left lane, also heading the same way.

2. **Frame 2:** Similar view, still nothing that directly indicates the one‐way direction, although the traffic flow remains consistent (all vehicles moving away from the camera in the same direction).

3. **Frame 3:** The overhead traffic light and cross‐street signs become a bit clearer. We can see a rectangular sign above the traffic light, but it is not fully legible yet.

4. **Frame 4:** Now the “ONE WAY” sign on the overhead mast arm is more visible—though slightly obscured, it appears to have an arrow pointing to the right. Traffic still flows uniformly away from the camera, with no oncoming cars.

5. **Frame 5:** The “ONE WAY” sign is easiest to read here: it has an arrow directing traffic to the right. This confirms that the cross street in front is one way going right.

**Contextual Reasoning:**  
All cars (including the tanker) move in the same direction along this road; we do not see any opposing traffic lanes or cars coming toward us. The overhead sign (particularly in Frames 4 and 5) explicitly shows “ONE WAY” with an arrow pointing to the right. Standard traffic rules dictate that such signs denote the required direction of travel on that roadway.

**Match to Answer Choices:**  
• A (Left) is inconsistent with the visible “ONE WAY →” signage in Frame 5.  
• B (Right) fits exactly with the sign’s arrow, showing the traffic must flow to the right.

<answer>Right</answer>
